persona.name: Kristian Solbakken

occupation.title: Senior Engineering Manager (Software)
occupation.organization: Midsize Oslo-based fintech company (payments / consumer finance)
occupation.description: Kristian manages a team of 12 engineers (full-stack + mobile) building backend services and customer-facing apps for personal finance and payments. His role spans technical leadership, hiring, performance management, setting technical roadmap priorities with product management, stakeholder communication with compliance and risk teams (given the regulated fintech environment), and participating in architectural decisions. He splits his time approximately 50% on people & process (1:1s, recruitment, mentoring), 30% on cross-team delivery coordination and roadmaps, and 20% on hands-on technical reviews and occasionally coding prototypes.
responsibilities: Hiring and onboarding engineers; shaping interview process and technical assessments.
Designing and enforcing engineering best practices (code review, CI/CD, incident post-mortems).
Coordinating releases with product owners, QA, security, and operations.
Budgeting for team headcount and tooling; advocating for resources with senior management.
Mentoring senior engineers and supporting career growth plans.
Translating regulatory requirements (KYC/AML, data residency) into implementation constraints with architects.
Leading technical responses during incidents and ensuring proper post-incident follow-up.
Representing engineering in product roadmap prioritization and trade-off discussions.
relevant_skills_and_expertise: System design for distributed services and APIs.
Backend technologies (experience with Java/Kotlin, Node.js, or Go) and cloud platforms (AWS/GCP).
Understanding of payments rails, integrations with banks, and basic financial instruments.
Product thinking and writing clear technical specifications.
Hiring, performance reviews, and building team culture.
Data pipelines and analytics for product telemetry.
Familiarity with security and compliance in fintech.

persona.education: Master of Science (MSc) in Informatics (Software Engineering), University of Oslo. Undergraduate studies in Computer Science at a Norwegian university college. Supplementary courses in financial technology and project management (Scrum Product Owner, PMP-style certificate courses), short executive training in leadership at BI Norwegian Business School. Erasmus semester in Eindhoven focused on human-computer interaction.
long_term_goals: To build and lead engineering teams that ship reliable, ethical financial products used across Europe.
To achieve financial independence so work is a choice, not necessity; reach comfortable early retirement in mid-50s.
To maintain a stable home life and provide good educational opportunities for his children.
To learn to play piano to comfortable standard and perform once at a small local venue.
To travel with his family to at least ten countries outside Europe, experiencing local music and culture.
To invest time and some money in mentoring younger engineers and occasional pro-bono civic tech projects.
To renovate and upgrade his apartment over the next five years to be energy-efficient and better for hosting friends.
To develop a small side project — a privacy-focused personal finance app — and deploy a viable MVP.
To become fluent in one additional European language (German) and retain high fluency in English and Norwegian.
To deepen his knowledge of product strategy so he can move into VP Product/CTO-level roles if desired.

style.general_way_of_being: Calm, pragmatic, professional but informal. Comfortable in both technical discussions and strategy meetings. He prefers clarity and directness but usually keeps a warm tone.
style.speech_and_language: Speaks Norwegian (Bokmål) natively and English fluently with a slight Oslo intonation when speaking Norwegian. Uses tech and management jargon when among colleagues but shifts to plain language for non-technical stakeholders. Prefers short, well-structured sentences in writing and often uses Slack for quick, direct communication.
mannerisms: Pauses briefly to think before answering tricky questions.
Leans forward slightly when someone tells a story he finds interesting.
Taps the corner of his notebook with a pen when thinking during meetings.
Uses understated humor — dry, self-deprecating comments to ease tension.
Often removes his jacket and rolls up sleeves in casual meetings.
Prefers to schedule 1:1s and keeps structured agendas.
Carries a compact Moleskine notebook and a fountain pen for sketching diagrams.
style.formal_vs_casual: Generally casual in day-to-day interactions (first-name basis), but reverts to a slightly more formal tone in town-hall settings or when talking with legal/compliance counterparts.
style.digital_communication_preferences: Prefers structured channels: Slack for day-to-day, email for formal documentation, Notion or Confluence for specs. Likes brief meeting notes and actionable next steps highlighted at top of messages.

traits: Pragmatic problem solver: focuses on concrete next steps rather than abstract debate.
Mentoring mindset: enjoys seeing people develop and takes time to coach.
Slight perfectionist when it comes to system reliability and product quality.
Socially warm but selective: close with a small group of friends; not one to network superficially.
Mildly competitive: enjoys friendly contests (board games, coding katas).
Curious learner: consumes books and podcasts about history, tech, and management.
Resilient under pressure: handles outages or customer escalations with composure.
Cautious decision-maker: likes data and input before committing to big changes.
Appreciates rituals and routines: coffee, weekend concerts, gym sessions.
Emotionally steady: prefers to process feelings privately, occasionally shares with partner or close friends.
personality.notes_on_big_five: High openness: enjoys cultural activities (museums, concerts) and trying new technologies. High conscientiousness: reliable, meets commitments, organizes teams. Moderate extraversion: comfortable in groups but requires downtime. High agreeableness: helpful, cooperative, but will push back when standards matter. Low-moderate neuroticism: generally calm, occasional stress during major incidents.

interests: Technology and gaming: follows gaming news, occasionally builds PCs, plays co-op games with friends (Rocket League, Civilization, recent indie titles).
Arts and culture: regular attendee of Oslo Philharmonic concerts, small theatre productions (Det Norske Teatret), and exhibitions at the National Museum and Astrup Fearnley.
Gadget enthusiast: enjoys evaluating new phones, headphones (favours neutral sound), and smart home devices.
Food and restaurants: enjoys trying modern Nordic cuisine, sushi, and good espresso.
Travel: city breaks in Europe that combine culture and music (Berlin, Lisbon, Barcelona).
Reading: non-fiction on business and history, occasional literary fiction and Nordic crime novels.
Podcasts: product management, system design, Norwegian history, and music interviews.
Board games: medium-weight strategy games shared with a close group (Terraforming Mars, Azul).
Exercise: strength training, cycling, and occasional weekend hikes in nearby Marka.
Photography: casual interest in architectural and concert photography (uses a mirrorless camera).
likes: Evenings at small concert venues where acoustics are good and the crowd is attentive.
Weekends spent mixing social time with family and a short afternoon at a museum.
Black, strong coffee in the morning; prefers a local roaster's espresso over chain coffee.
Well-designed consumer products that balance form and function (Muji, Apple, Bang & Olufsen aesthetics).
Collaborating with cross-functional teams that respect engineering constraints.
Buying board games as an excuse to host a game night.
Efficient public transport; reliable trains and trams in Oslo.
Minimalist home décor with a few striking art pieces.
Gifts that reflect thoughtfulness rather than price.
dislikes: Open-plan offices that are noisy and reduce focus.
Endless, unstructured meetings with no clear outcome.
Poorly designed digital products with confusing user flows.
Excessive bureaucracy that slows product delivery.
Low-quality sound at concerts or bad seating sightlines.
Unreliable flight connections on business trips.
Superficial small talk at networking events.
High-latency online games and poor server performance.
music_preferences: Classical: enjoys chamber music and symphonies (frequent attendee at Oslo Philharmonic).
Indie and alternative rock: follows a few Scandinavian bands and boutique labels.
Electronic: chill techno and downtempo for focused work sessions.
Soundtracks: appreciates film and game scores for relaxation and inspiration.
Live music preference: intimate venues and good acoustics over festival crowds.
gaming_preferences: Platform: primarily PC, sometimes Nintendo Switch for co-op titles.
Types: enjoys strategy (4X, grand strategy), narrative-driven adventures, and competitive co-op multiplayer.
Play style: weekend evening sessions with friends; competitive but sportsmanlike.
Favorite recent titles: indie narrative game, a strategy expansion, and cooperative shooters.
Hardware: comfortable building/upgrading PCs; prefers mechanical keyboard with brown switches.
arts_and_culture_details: Museum routine: monthly visit to rotating exhibitions; season ticket to the National Museum appeals.
Theatre: attends premieres at Det Norske Teatret, occasionally the National Theatre for classics.
Concert venues: enjoys ticketed events at Sentrum scene for smaller acts, Oslo Konserthus for larger classical programs.
Art tastes: contemporary Norwegian painters and sculptors; has a small collection of prints and local photography.
Memberships: holds a membership to a local cultural association for early ticket access.
food_and_drink: Morning ritual: espresso, skimmed milk if at a café; at home uses a small espresso machine.
Favorite snacks: dark chocolate, salted almonds, and a seasonal selection of berries in summer.
Dining out: prefers restaurants that clearly indicate provenance of ingredients.
Cooking: enjoys making weekday pasta dishes and weekend grilling with friends.
Alcohol: drinks wine and occasional craft beer; dislikes overly sweet cocktails.
leisure_tech_and_subscriptions: Uses a premium music streaming service and pays for an audiobook subscription.
Subscribes to a couple of technical newsletters and one business magazine.
Has household subscriptions to a streaming video service and a local sports streaming package.
Uses a VPN and password manager; values digital privacy tools.
travel_and_vacation: Prefers city breaks combined with one week-long family holiday in quieter nature locations each year.
Enjoys exploring local music scenes while traveling.
Values efficient itineraries with time for museum visits and a few restaurant reservations.
Comfortable with mid-range business class flights for longer trips depending on cost and company policy.

beliefs: Strong belief in Norway's welfare model as a social safety net that enables risk-taking in career and entrepreneurship.
Favors pragmatic, evidence-based public policy rather than ideological extremes.
Believes digital products should respect user privacy by default; minimal data collection.
Wary of Big Tech monopolies; supports competitive markets and open standards.
Sees regulation (especially in fintech) as necessary to protect consumers, even if it introduces friction.
Values honesty and transparency in leadership and corporate communication.
Believes in mentorship and the multiplier effect of senior engineers investing time in juniors.
Thinks continuous learning is essential: technology evolves too quickly to remain static.
Supports strong public education and vocational pathways for technical careers.
Believes in a balanced life: work is important but shouldn't eclipse family and health.
Prefers collaboration over internal competition; dysfunction from politics lowers team performance.
Believes investments in reliability and testing pay off long-term compared with rushing features.
Against needlessly punitive corporate cultures; performance management must be fair and documented.
Believes in paying taxes conscientiously; expects efficient public services in return.
Sees climate change as a serious risk that should influence personal and corporate choices (reduce waste, energy efficiency).
Values cultural institutions (museums, orchestras) as essential to civic life and personal enrichment.
Believes childcare and parental leave policies are crucial to gender equality at work.
Favors pragmatic immigration policy that integrates skilled workers while supporting social cohesion.
Believes in investing in mental health support in the workplace to reduce burnout and improve retention.
Sees open-source software as an important public good and contributes occasionally.
Believes in clear separation between product and regulatory compliance teams to preserve focus and expertise.
Prefers companies that adopt long-term product vision over quarterly growth-at-all-costs thinking.
Believes good design is an ethical responsibility: products should be accessible and inclusive.
Supports local cultural funding and small venues as incubators for new talent.
Believes in incremental improvement — small experiments, measure, learn, iterate.
Sees mentorship and sponsorship as distinct; both are needed for equitable career advancement.
Believes in personal financial prudence: save consistently, diversify investments, avoid excessive leverage.
Believes managing technical debt is as important as delivering new features; it's a strategic choice.
Values empirical leadership: use metrics but understand their limits.
Believes in negotiating calmly and professionally; burning bridges rarely helps long-term.
Sees trust in institutions as fragile — transparency and accountability help maintain it.
Believes in healthy skepticism toward hyped technologies; evaluate them based on fit and ROI.
Believes in community involvement: supporting local schools, cultural groups, and neighborhood initiatives.
Believes in family as primary emotional support but also recognizes chosen family (close friends) are essential.
Believes that a good leader admits mistakes publicly and learns from them.
skills: Technical: system architecture for cloud-native services, service-oriented design, API design and versioning.
Programming: practical experience with Java/Kotlin and Node.js; comfortable reading and reviewing Go or Python code.
DevOps familiarity: CI/CD pipelines (Jenkins/GitHub Actions), container orchestration (Kubernetes), monitoring (Prometheus/Grafana).
Data: basic SQL, ability to read analytics dashboards and define telemetry needs.
Product: translating customer needs into technical requirements, building MVPs, A/B test design basics.
Management: hiring, conducting structured 1:1s, career development plans, and running performance reviews.
Communication: crafting clear technical proposals, stakeholder presentations, and executive summaries.
Security & compliance: awareness of KYC/AML processes, data residency, and secure coding practices.
Languages: native Norwegian (Bokmål), fluent English, intermediate German.
Soft skills: conflict resolution, mentorship, time management, prioritization, strategic planning.

general: Prefers to write a short summary and next actions at the top of every message or document.
Blocks deep work time on his calendar and defends it from ad-hoc meetings.
Keeps a small set of routines: morning espresso, gym thrice weekly, family dinner most nights.
When stressed, goes for a short walk to clear his head before responding.
Uses music (instrumental) to focus when coding or reviewing architecture.
Brings home small museum catalogues and reads them with his partner on weekends.
Regularly volunteers as a judge for university hackathons or guest-lectures occasionally.

morning: Makes espresso, reads a 20-minute roundup of tech and business news while eating a slice of wholegrain bread.
Does a short mobility routine or a 30-minute gym session thrice weekly.
Prepares kids' lunches occasionally and exchanges quick morning check-ins with his partner.
Skims email and Slack for critical items, then closes everything for one 90-minute deep work block.
workday: Starts with the most important deep work: architecture reviews or writing spec drafts.
Holds two 1:1s per day on scheduled days; weekly leadership team sync on Tuesdays.
Lunch: usually a quick walk and a sandwich or sushi nearby; sometimes joins a developer lunch for social time.
Afternoons: coordination, meetings with product and compliance, code reviews in short bursts.
Ends official work day by 16:30–17:30 when possible to pick up kids or attend an event.
evening: Family dinner at home most evenings; if there's a concert or social event, organizes it around kids' bedtimes.
Spends 30–60 minutes on a personal project or reading technical articles.
Occasional late-night co-op gaming sessions with an old college friend on weekends.
Pre-bed routine includes checking a short list of tomorrow's priorities and reading a chapter of a book.
weekend: Saturday: morning gym or hike, museum visit or theatre matinee, grocery shopping, relaxed cooking.
Sunday: family time, small house maintenance tasks, preparing lunches for the week, light catch-up on personal projects.
Hosts or attends a monthly board game night with a close circle of friends.

health.general_health: Good overall health. Regular exercise and generally balanced diet.
medical_history: Mild seasonal hay fever (uses antihistamines occasionally).
Former minor sports injury (rolled ankle in twenties) that occasionally flares with heavy hiking.
Annual check-ups normal; watches cholesterol and blood pressure as part of routine monitoring.
mental_health: Stable mental health with periods of higher stress associated with work deadlines or major incidents.
Practices informal stress-coping: short walks, workouts, and talking through problems with partner.
Believes in seeking professional help when necessary; used a company-provided counselor once after a particularly stressful quarter.
lifestyle: Sleeps around 7 hours per night when routines are steady; occasionally interrupted by travel or child care.
Moderate alcohol consumption (social wine or beer), avoids heavy drinking.
Aims for three strength-training sessions per week and weekly cycling or hiking.

relationships.name: Ingrid

A network of former classmates (NTNU and University of Oslo), a small circle of ex-colleagues in other fintech companies, and a local leadership peer group that meets quarterly to discuss management challenges.
Small core group of 5–8 close friends from university and early career; meet monthly for game nights, concerts, or dinner.
An elderly neighbor who appreciates Kristian mowing common balcony plants and helps with small errands occasionally.

First computer was a Commodore 64; an early curiosity about programming led to choosing informatics in school.
Did an Erasmus semester in Eindhoven where he discovered small-venue live music and a lasting interest in European city architecture.
Loves attending classical concerts and once unexpectedly met a favorite cellist after a performance.
Served on the committee that established a youth coding workshop at a local library.
Bought his Frogner apartment five years ago with a mortgage; he prioritized proximity to parks and cultural venues.
Has a small flat-packed workshop corner at home for electronics tinkering and minor woodwork.
Once led a critical on-call incident involving a payment failure at 03:00; organized the team, communicated with customers, and ran a blameless post-mortem.
Is an amateur photographer and has a modest Instagram account focusing on architecture and concert photography (private account for close friends).
Has a simple investment portfolio: index funds, a couple of blue-chip Norwegian stocks, and a small allocation to a responsible tech startup.
Enjoys Nordic crime novels and once read an entire series on a long winter vacation.
Volunteers as a guest lecturer at his former university on software engineering career paths.
Has a ritual of buying a print from an exhibition he enjoys as a memento every few years.
Values punctuality; usually arrives 5–10 minutes early for meetings and events.
Has a childhood memory of a family summer cabin in Telemark that shaped his appreciation for low-tech nature retreats.
Learned to cook decent weekday meals during early-career days to save money and enjoys experimenting with a new sauce or spice combination.
Owns an electric bicycle for commuting when weather permits and prefers it to driving inside the city.
Is slightly embarrassed about a failed startup attempt in his late 20s but views it as a formative learning experience.
Maintains a list of books he plans to read; uses a simple Kanban board for personal projects.
Once helped his sister move apartments at 2 AM after a logistics fiasco and remembers it as an exhausting but bonding experience.
Has a pragmatic attitude towards charity: prefers recurring small donations to causes he trusts rather than one-off large sums.
Is attentive to sustainability where convenient: recycles diligently, replaced most bulbs with LEDs, and installed better insulation during a minor renovation.
Keeps an emergency bag in his car with jumper cables, a small first-aid kit, a thermal blanket, and a toolkit.
Was the captain of his high-school debate team; still appreciates structured argumentation and good evidence.
Has a recurring concern about balancing increasing responsibilities at work with time for family and personal projects.
Knows how to change a bicycle tire, do basic soldering on electronics projects, and configure a home NAS for backups.
Once took a month-long parental leave and found it transformative for his relationship with his son and partner.
Collects concert tickets and keeps them in a box as physical memories of events attended over the years.
Has a friendly rivalry with a college friend about who can maintain the best aquarium (they both gave it up for time reasons).
Keeps a well-worn copy of a systems design book on his shelf and occasionally annotates it with new insights from his work.
Believes small rituals (like a Saturday morning espresso ritual) anchor his weeks and reduce decision fatigue.
Has a low tolerance for wasteful meetings and is known to propose efficient alternatives (asynchronous updates, short syncs).
Attended a week-long leadership retreat once and still uses a communication framework learned there when giving feedback.
Once volunteered with a local refugee support organisation helping with language and employment orientation.
Is mildly superstitious about always backing up before making big deploys and chants a private mnemonic for deploy steps as a joke.
Has a recurring dream to one day host a small speaker series in his living room combining technology, music and food for neighbors and friends.
Owns a small record of embarrassing karaoke performances from university days; enjoys the memory and laughs about it with friends.
